header.title: Austin Osman Spare's Magical System: An Analysis from The Scroll of Set (June 1976)

central_thesis: This article introduces Austin Osman Spare's unique and individualistic magical system, primarily centered on the concepts of Zos and Kia and the practical application of Sigilization, positioning it as a powerful operative magical current worthy of Setian investigation due to its emphasis on subconscious power and atavistic forms, resonating with the Temple of Set's principles of self-deification and exploration of 'bestial-attributed Egyptian gods'.

structure_content.summary: Michael A. Aquino V° reviews the Temple of Set's foundational year since its reestablishment, contrasting its structured, Priesthood-driven administration with the chaotic, leader-centric Church of Satan. He details the creation of the Temple's legal framework (Articles of Incorporation, By-Laws), its formal recognition as a tax-exempt religious institution, and the establishment of various administrative offices (Executive Director, data-processing, publication, research, financial, communications, contingency planning). The article highlights a slow, quality-focused growth strategy, emphasizing individual initiative for advancement and distinguishing the Temple's purpose (Xeper) from hedonism. It also outlines future goals, including publishing 'The Book of Coming Forth by Night' and 'Ruby Tablet of Set', and expanding administrative services.

James Lewis I° presents a personal reflection on abortion, expressing ethical concerns from a Setian perspective. Drawing on his experience as a scrub nurse, he questions the destruction of the unborn, positing a potential 'magus of tomorrow' and querying accountability to 'the Dark Lord' for such an act, thereby introducing a moral dilemma within the Setian worldview.

structure_content.chapter_title: Austin Osman Spare: For Those Artistically Minded
structure_content.summary: Leon Marvell I° provides a comprehensive overview of Austin Osman Spare's life, artistic style, philosophical underpinnings, and practical magical system. Spare, a British artist and sorcerer (1888-1956), developed a unique system distinct from Hermeticism, influenced by 'Mrs. Peterson' and later breaking with Crowley. The core of his philosophy includes Zos (the holistic self) and Kia (a primal, dynamic, sexual energy of the Universe). Marvell details Spare's central magical technique of Sigilization, as well as the creation of stelæ and the 'Death Posture' for 'atavistic resurgence'. The article also explores Spare's involvement with the English witch-cult (Gardner, Grant) and suggests the relevance of his 'bestial-attributed Egyptian gods' for Setian initiates.

key_concepts.definition: The self considered as a whole; the entire life of an individual, encompassing a succession of existences and atavisms, many of which are bestial and potentially super-human. It is the individual's totality, including subconscious memories and potentials.

The primal, dynamic, and incalculably subtle and powerful energy behind the Universe, likened to 'Black Magical ordering force', Reich's 'bion'/'orgone' energy, and Tantric 'Kundalini'. Later considered primarily sexual in nature, Kia is the medium of Spare's magic and is identified with Zos during his 'Zos Kia Cultus' period, representing the autonomous self's energy.

A practical magical technique developed by Spare to manifest desires. It involves defining a desire clearly, reducing it to a stylized glyph (sigil) by combining individual letters, impressing this sigil upon the subconscious mind through intense concentration, visualization, and sometimes sex-magic (when the ego is 'destroyed'), and then consciously 'forgetting' the sigil's meaning to allow the subconscious (source of Kia) to fulfill the desire.

The magical effect aimed for by operations such as stelæ design and specific art. It refers to the evocation and utilization of 'forces within the psyche' conceived as memories of bestial and other past incarnations (atavisms). These atavisms are considered superior to the conscious ego and can possess the individual for a specific purpose and time, linking to 'bestial-attributed Egyptian gods'.

A sensory deprival technique employed by Spare to enter a subconscious state. By retiring into the subconscious mind, the practitioner aims to access 'sidereal perspectives' and perceive 'strange geometries and landscapes', visions that Spare attempted to reproduce artistically.

(Contextual to the Temple of Set) A fundamental Setian concept signifying a 'sense of purpose or direction'. While not explicitly defined in the provided text beyond this, its usage implies self-creation, becoming, and the active pursuit of one's unique will, distinguishing Setianism from aimless hedonism.

practical_system.description: Austin Osman Spare's magical system is an intensely personal and artistic operative methodology, diverging from conventional occult traditions. It posits the subconscious mind as the ultimate source of magical power (Kia) and focuses on directly impressing desires upon it, rather than relying on external deities or complex ritual hierarchies. The system emphasizes harnessing primal, atavistic energies ('atavistic resurgence') inherent within the 'Zos' (holistic self) and utilizes artistic creation—drawings, paintings, and glyphs—as central magical acts.
tools: Subconscious Mind: The primary magical 'tool', regarded as the source of Kia and the locus for fulfilling magically impressed desires.
Pencil and Artistic Mediums: Utilized for the creation of sigils, stelæ, and other magical artwork, which function as conduits or operators for subconscious impression.
Body/Sensory Deprivation: The physical self is used to induce altered states for practices like the Death Posture and sex-magic, facilitating access to deeper psychic layers and the arousal of Kia.
rituals: Sigilization: Defining a desire clearly, transcribing it into a sigil by combining letters, impressing the sigil onto the subconscious through intense concentration, visualization, and sometimes sex-magic (when the ego is 'destroyed'), followed by conscious 'forgetting' of the sigil's meaning to allow subconscious manifestation.

Stelæ Design: Creating continuous line drawings or paintings incorporating god-forms (from various cultures, including unknown origins), atavistic forms, personal sigils, and esoteric glyphs. These stelæ, with their non-linear temporal concepts, serve as 'doorways' intended to induce 'atavistic resurgence'.

Death Posture: A sensory deprival technique used to consciously withdraw into the subconscious mind to perceive 'sidereal perspectives' and 'strange geometries and landscapes', aiming for a deeper, non-rational gnosis.
Sex-Magic: Employed to arouse 'concentrated Kia', which is considered the medium of magic, and to impress sigils onto the subconscious, particularly in states where the ego is 'destroyed'.
'Primeval Sexualism': A practice linked to Kia, aimed at realizing 'ancient desires' or atavisms to achieve a 'whole' self.

relevant_quotes.text: The use of the final sigil consisted of impressing its image on the subconscious mind and then purposely 'forgetting' it - the idea being that the subconscious was the source of all magical power (Kia) and that the subconscious would recognize the hidden meaning of the glyph (which the conscious mind had 'forgotten') and fulfill the desire.
His most important magical contribution is his concept of 'Sigilization'.
Zos was the self considered as a whole - that is, the entire life of an individual, a succession of existences or atavisms, many of them bestial and some possibly super-human.

Kia was the primal force behind the Universe [like the Black Magical concept of the 'ordering' force]: a dynamic - as opposed to static - energy - like electricity except incalculably more subtle and powerful. Later in his life he considered Kia to be primarily sexual in nature.
Spare's experiments with 'atavistic resurgence' probably inclined him to believe that he had discovered the true significance behind bestial-attributed Egyptian gods.
The initiative for your advancement and education rests with you; the Temple is a sort of 'institutional accessory' to help you.
Suppose the fetus aborted today was to have been the magus of tomorrow? Which one of us wishes to answer to the Dark Lord for this act?

critical_analysis.relevance: This article is highly relevant to Western Esotericism, particularly for its detailed exposition of Austin Osman Spare's system, which serves as a significant precursor to modern Chaos Magic due to its emphasis on sigilization and subconscious manipulation, bypassing traditional dogma. For the Temple of Set, its publication in 'The Scroll of Set' signifies an exploration of magical currents that align with Setian principles of individual will, self-deification (Xeper), and the potential for tapping into 'bestial-attributed Egyptian gods.' The explicit suggestion for Setians to investigate Spare's system indicates its value as a tool for personal gnosis and operative magic within the Setian context, providing a non-traditional, artistically integrated path to magical attainment.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of initiates of the Temple of Set, particularly those at III°+ levels, seeking advanced practical magical knowledge and philosophical depth. Beyond this, it caters to occult practitioners, academics, and enthusiasts interested in the history and evolution of modern magical practices, especially sigil magic, and the works of Austin Osman Spare. Its technical nature and detailed descriptions make it suitable for those with a foundational understanding of esoteric concepts.
